Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing Engineers who Return from Industry to Earn a PhD, and Their Impact on Innovation

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project seeks to understand the motivations and contributions of engineers who return from industry positions to pursue Ph.D. degrees. This project hypothesizes that such students can play key roles in building bridges between academia and industry, and may play important roles in the innovation ecosystem. By helping to increase understanding of this student population, the proposed research can help universities recruit, retain, and maximize the potential of such students.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be to impact academic policy and recruitment strategies, as well as contribute to research-based best practices. If the project is successful, the research can have broad impact on the research community, innovation policy, as well as government programs designed to support student research. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by creating results and research that are useful for society by informing educational policy and practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a well-documented need for highly skilled engineers, including those with doctoral level training, in engineering practice and research. In order to best address complex societal issues, these engineers must possess both technical proficiency and the perspectives and experience necessary to recognize important problems and develop innovative engineering solutions. To increase the number of engineers in the workforce and ensure diversity of perspectives and experiences that facilitate greater innovation and problem-solving within the field as a whole, it is critical that we consider and support multiple pathways through doctoral engineering education.

One largely overlooked pathway through engineering education is that of returners, students who pursue advanced engineering study after significant professional experience. In our project, we focused specifically on PhD-level engineering returners. We contrast returners with direct-pathway students, who pursue a PhD shortly after completing a baccalaureate, the more “typical” path through engineering education. Returning students with extensive professional experience can contribute to the intellectual and experiential diversity with engineering and are likely to bring both technical skills and distinct insight into applied engineering problems to their academic work.

While returners represent an underutilized pathway through advanced engineering study and may be particularly well poised to contribute to innovative solutions to important engineering problems, little prior research exists about returning students. Our 3-phase study consisted of:

1) a national survey characterizing the PhD experiences of returning and direct-pathway students and their decisions to pursue a PhD,

2) interviews with returning and direct-pathway students focused on students’ PhD research work and how their past experiences may shape their research decisions and approaches, and

3) interviews with engineering professionals in industry and government organizations focused on workplace practices, policies, and attitudes that may shape employees’ decision-making about returning for a doctorate.

Collectively, our findings provide greater insight into who returning students are, their reasons for pursuing doctoral study, motivations and thinking about their academic work, intersections between their past experience and current research, and elements of their academic and professional environments that may advance or inhibit their persistence and success in engineering PhD programs.

We found that, compared to direct-pathway students, returners recalled lower levels of confidence in their ability to successfully complete a PhD prior to enrolling. Returners also reported higher levels of perceived academic, financial, and work-life balance costs associated with pursuing a PhD These differences could have implications for returners’ decisions to enroll or persist in engineering PhD programs and suggest specific areas in which universities may be able to target support for these returning students. In many cases, institutions could leverage existing resources, such as childcare services, fellowships or emergency funding sources, and statistics or software training courses.  These findings, and the emphasis of our larger project, hopefully also raise awareness of returners as a demographic within engineering doctoral programs who may have distinct experiences or needs. Awareness of, and the ability to identify returning students is key in promoting their success and thus supporting greater diversity of experiences of those students who pursue and complete advanced engineering training.

Our findings also pointed to a number of ways returners’ distinct perspectives may shape their approaches to engineering research. We explored students’ rationale for pursuing a particular topic of research and found that many students chose an area of study based on external factors such as funding or an advisor’s urging. However, returners more frequently reported intrinsic motivation for selecting a topic of research, often citing past experiences they drew on in identifying an important problem they hoped to solve or the skills to solve that problem. Intrinsic motivation is associated with greater enjoyment of and success at a particular task. Our findings of differences in returning and direct-pathways students’ motivation for research topic selection point to opportunities to provide more students with the chance to explore topics of interest prior to settling on a primary research area.

 We also developed a holistic classification scheme for assessing the different types and levels of awareness engineering doctoral students bring to solving a research problem. A substantially higher proportion of returning students in our study demonstrate the highest levels of research awareness and sophistication. This highest level of research sophistication is broadly characterized by awareness of and strategic thinking about a number of technical and non-technical elements of directing a research project, including consideration of funding and other resources, collaborating with others, and engaging with stakeholders. Returners and other students who demonstrated a high level of research process sophistication expressed a clear direction and confidence in their decision making which was informed, but not threatened by, input from others. Supporting students in the development of greater research awareness and better utilizing the expertise of those who already demonstrate sophisticated research processes has implications for promoting high-quality engineering research that can be effectively shared and applied.
